intro: Balanophora abbreviata, commonly known as the dwarf ghost orchid, is a rare and elusive orchid species native to the tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia. It is a mycoheterotrophic plant, meaning it lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on fungal associations for its nutrition. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that are typically clustered in a spike, and it has a short, stocky stem with reduced leaves. Due to its specialized ecological requirements, it is highly sensitive to habitat disturbance and is considered endangered in many regions. Its unique botanical features make it a subject of interest for both botanists and conservationists.
